entry.title: Japan‚Äôs cabinet approves record defense budget that aims to deter China; AP explains
entry.summary: Japan's Cabinet approved Friday a record defense budget plan exceeding 9 trillion yen ($58 billion) for the coming year.

author.name: China | Latest News from China Today | AP News

entry.title: Here‚Äôs where NASA is looking for life in our solar system
entry.summary:
A composite view of Mars taken by the Viking I and II probes. From Viking to Perseverance, scientists have spent decades chasing chemical hints that could point to life beyond Earth.
In September, NASA announced the discovery of a possible sign of life, known as a potential biosignature, on Mars. The Perseverance rover, which has been exploring a dried-up lakebed for years, found traces of ancient redox reactions, which can be produced by either life or geological processes.¬†
Though the origin of the reactions remains unclear, the tantalizing discovery represents the latest chapter in the search for biosignatures on alien worlds. For a half-century, scientists have been fascinated and flummoxed by ambiguous compounds and structures on our neighboring planets‚Äîand increasingly, ‚Ä¶

entry.title: See 15 striking travel photos of 2025
entry.summary:
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
Selecting the best travel images from a year‚Äôs worth of fantastic photography is quite a challenge when the photographers have travelled to all corners of the world to document features for National Geographic Traveller (UK). From the snowy peaks of Greenland and sun-kissed hills of Bhutan to the cowboys of Ecuador and lions on the prowl in South Africa, these images all capture natural moments of beauty, personality and culture from the world around us.
Ben Rowe, picture editor and Aisha Nazar, associate picture editor
A pride of lions in pursuit of a lioness who has strayed onto their territory at the Phinda Game Reserve in South Africa. Photographer Jonathan Gregson captured this encounter while on assi‚Ä¶

entry.title: Is there archaeological evidence for the Biblical fall of Jericho?
entry.summary:
The fall of Jericho is one of the most popular stories in the Bible. According to the Old Testament, Israelites‚Äîa group of Hebrew people whom Moses had led out of Egypt‚Äîconquered the city of Jericho in dramatic fashion: At the direction of God, they surrounded the city, blew on horns, and, with a little divine help, the blast was so powerful that it knocked¬†over the city‚Äôs heavy walls. The story showcased the might of God and argued that the Israelites were his chosen people.¬†
Jericho wasn‚Äôt just a biblical city. Modern Jericho still exists in Palestine‚Äôs West Bank and is popularly considered¬†one of the world's oldest cities. The ruins of Jericho‚Äôs ancient remains are located just outside the sprawling modern city center. These ancient remains are now the¬†UNESCO World Heritage¬†site Te‚Ä¶

entry.title: Inside the bone-crushing mating rituals of dinosaurs
entry.summary: An Olorotitan dinosaur fossil with fractured tail vertebrae has resurrected a theory around how dinosaurs mated. A handful of unique fossils are spilling the secrets of dinosaur courtship and reproduction.  Whatever happened to the duck-billed dinosaur, it was a real pain in the butt. Many of the spines sitting atop the animal‚Äôs tail vertebrae had been fractured. The dinosaur, known as Olorotitan to paleontologists, wasn‚Äôt simply clumsy; too many bones were broken. The breaks were more consistent with some heavy downward pressure right near the base of the tail. At 26 feet long and three tons, another Olorotitan would have been large enough to do such damage.¬† Institute of Natural Sciences in Brussels paleontologist Filippo Bertozzo had ventured to Blagoveshchensk‚Ä¶

entry.title: How travel will look in 2026‚Äîhere's what you need to know
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
This year is shaping up to be one of travel niches. Night owls will be embracing their dark sides and teetotallers will be enjoying juice pairings, while literary types will be looking to plan bookish getaways and runners will start lacing up in new¬†surroundings. Meanwhile, all-inclusives are making a comeback (with a difference), and more of us are set to experience life on the farm. Plus, AI ‚Äî and bot booking agents‚Äî will continue to transform the way we travel. These are the latest trends set to shape how we see the world.
For night owls, travel has never been more exciting. ‚ÄòNoctourism‚Äô, or nocturnal tourism, is booming, covering everything from stargazing and night-time safaris to after-dark city tours a‚Ä¶

entry.title: China eases IPO rules for firms developing reusable rockets
entry.summary: Chinese companies developing reusable commercial rockets will have access to a fast lane for initial public offerings on the tech-heavy STAR market that exempts them from some financial requirements, the Shanghai Stock Exchange said on Friday.

entry.title: Sudan civil war: Health system ‚Äòon the verge of collapse‚Äô
entry.summary: The war in Sudan has been tearing the country apart for almost 1,000 days, putting the country‚Äôs health system under intolerable pressure. The World Health Organization (WHO) is reporting widespread disease outbreaks, severe shortages, malnutrition and rising deaths.

entry.title: Sri Lanka cyclone: More than a million still need aid weeks after Ditwah floods
entry.summary: Nearly a month after Cyclone Ditwah tore across Sri Lanka, more than a million people ‚Äì including over half a million children ‚Äì remain in urgent need of humanitarian assistance, as floods, landslides and renewed rainfall continue to compound one of the country‚Äôs worst disasters in decades.

entry.title: First Person: Felipe Paullier, the youngest ever senior UN official, charged with giving a voice to young people around the world
entry.summary: A paediatrician by training, Felipe Paullier has long been an advocate for youth. Formerly Director of the Uruguayan Government's Youth Institute, a role which involved several joint actions with various UN agencies, he was appointed to run the¬†UN Youth Office¬†in 2023, the youngest senior appointment in United Nations history.

entry.title: China sanctions 20 US defense companies and 10 executives over massive arms sales to Taiwan
entry.summary: Beijing has imposed sanctions on 20 U.S. defense-related companies and 10 executives. This move comes a week after Washington announced large-scale arms sales to Taiwan.

entry.title: Former China Life president expelled from Communist Party after corruption probe
entry.summary: The former president of China Life Insurance , Yang Chao, was expelled from the Communist Party after an investigation by China's anti-graft watchdog found he had committed violations including accepting bribes, the agency said in a statement on Friday.

entry.title: China hits US defence firms with sanctions over arms sales to Taiwan
entry.summary: China's foreign ministry announced sanctions on Friday targeting 10 individuals and 20 U.S. defence firms, including Boeing's St. Louis branch, over arms sales to Taiwan.

entry.title: ASIA GOLD Record gold rally cools Indian buying; China discounts narrow
entry.summary: Gold discounts in India widened to their highest in more than six months this week as a relentless price rally curbed retail buying, while discounts in China narrowed sharply from last week's five-year highs.

entry.title: Asia stocks rise to six-week high; precious metals on a tear
entry.summary: Asian stocks rose to their highest in six weeks on Friday and a blistering rally in precious metals showed no signs of tempering as investors sought to close out the year on a high while a softer yen kept intervention risk in the fray.

entry.title: Japanese Cabinet approves record defense spending
entry.summary: Japan‚Äôs Cabinet has approved a record defense budget plan exceeding 9 trillion yen for the coming year.

entry.title: Inside London's most beautiful and unique private members' clubs
entry.summary:
The Library at The Reform Club, designed by Charles Barry in 1853 with an 1878 color scheme by his son, EM Barry. Getting access to London's private members' clubs is a rare occurrence for most people, but now you can see what these often-secretive spaces look like.
It‚Äôs hard enough to imagine getting inside London‚Äôs exclusive members‚Äô clubs, let alone being allowed to ogle all the details. Which is a shame, because some of the most memorable and important works of architecture and design in this historic city can be found behind these guarded doors.¬†
Few libraries can compete with the gasp-inducing beauty of the Athenaeum, and influencers would likely trample over each other to be allowed to shoot on many of the clubs‚Äô elegant staircases.
Luckily, a gorgeous new book,¬†Th‚Ä¶

entry.title: Explore S√°mi crafts on a road trip through Swedish Lapland
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
With 24 saunas to 23 residents, it‚Äôs fair to say the village of Liehitt√§j√§ has at least one more sauna than is strictly necessary. Spend any time here, however, and you soon understand the ratio ‚Äî this is not, you‚Äôll see, a community that does things by halves.
Seventeen of those 23 residents belong to the same family, and I meet three of them one winter‚Äôs morning when the thermometer sits some way below zero and a gentle snowfall drifts from a leaden sky. It adds to the piles disguising the farm machinery and stacks of timber left in front yards, and introduces some extra peril to the clumps balancing precariously on the branches of spruce and birch. It‚Äôs a world of monochrome simplicity: white snow, dark trees, d‚Ä¶

entry.title: What is 'skimo'? It's the coolest new Winter Olympics sport
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
If you‚Äôve never heard of ski mountaineering before, you‚Äôre not alone. The competitive face of ski touring, this little-known sport involves climbing up a mountain then gliding down on skis, testing both the endurance and skill of enthusiasts. Scottish mountain guide Di Gilbert set out to popularise it in 2012, when she founded SkiMo Scotland ‚Äî the UK‚Äôs only company to organise ‚Äòskimo‚Äô races ‚Äî and began campaigning to get it recognised as an official speciality in the country. With the discipline soon debuting at the Milano Cortina 2026 Winter Olympics, it might finally get the attention she feels it deserves.
My mother ‚Äî northeast Scotland born and bred ‚Äî was quite formidable. I grew up in the countryside and was‚Ä¶

entry.title: China accuses US of distorting its defence policy in relation to India ties
entry.summary: China firmly opposes the U.S. Pentagon distorting its national defence policy, the foreign ministry said, referring to a mention of the development of China's ties with India in a report on the country.

entry.title: China says it hopes firms seek lawful, balanced solutions over TikTok deal
entry.summary: The Chinese government would like to see companies reach solutions that comply with Chinese laws and regulations and balance the interests of all parties, a commerce ministry spokesperson said on Thursday when asked about the hand-over of TikTok's U.S. operations.

entry.title: Foreign-branded phone shipments in China more than doubled on year in Nov, CAICT data shows
entry.summary: Shipments of foreign-branded mobile phones, including Apple's iPhones, rose 128.4% in China in November from the same month last year, according to Reuters calculations based on data released by a government-affiliated research firm on Thursday.

entry.title: China social media thrashes one-child policy after population control czar dies
entry.summary: The death of a former head of China's one-child policy has been met not by tributes but by castigation of the abandoned policy on social media this week.

entry.title: Looking for your next family adventure? Try an expedition cruise
entry.summary:
Between May and September, a group excursion with National Geographic-Lindblad Expeditions into Alaska‚Äôs Inian Islands archipelago guest-stars bald eagles and humpback whales. Who said expedition cruising was only for grown ups? Here are four family voyages for young explorers and conservationists.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
With a growing number of tour operators and cruise lines offering intrepid family voyages, expedition cruising is no longer just for grown-ups. From following in the footsteps of Charles Darwin in the Gal√°pagos Islands to charting a course through Alaska‚Äôs wildest corners as part of National Geographic‚Äôs Explorers-in-Training programme, these expedition cruises offer young conservationists and budding adventurers the‚Ä¶

entry.title: The industrial waste site that glitters like a glacier
entry.summary:
As a travel content creator, Atul Chaurasiya is always on the lookout for unique and offbeat locations. When he came across videos of the Kishangarh Dumping Yard on YouTube, he decided to visit the site.
Located about 62 miles south of Rajasthan‚Äôs capital city Jaipur, Kishangarh is Asia‚Äôs largest marble market. At the city‚Äôs outskirts lies this marble industry‚Äôs dumpsite, a ‚Äúgenuinely beautiful‚Äù place, according to Chaurasiya‚Äîwhite mountains that resemble snow-covered peaks and a contrast to Rajasthan's otherwise arid landscape. The influencer created a reel about the location in September 2023, and the Instagram post garnered over 250,000 likes.

entry.title: A culinary revival is taking place in northern Poland‚Äîhere's why
entry.summary:
The Mot≈Çawa river is one of many waterways webbing the city of Gda≈Ñsk and testament to its seafaring legacy. On the Baltic Sea in Poland‚Äôs far north, the tricity region combines Hanseatic seafaring heritage with Polish, German and Kashubian cooking. centuries-old recipes are being revived and the city of Gda≈Ñsk celebrated with a ‚Äòculinary capital‚Äô designation.

entry.title: From ‚ÄòWatchers‚Äô to baby cherubs: A brief history of angel myths
entry.summary:
In ancient Judaism and early Christianity, angels were portrayed as powerful beings who guarded the Garden of Eden, chronicled the deeds of humans, and heralded the Messiah's birth. Far from the baby-cheeked cherubs of Renaissance art, they were fiery beings who inspired fear.
Angels are among the most comforting religious figures in the modern imagination, radiant winged beings who hover peacefully above Nativity scenes each December. Indeed, their presence in the Christmas story is integral to the unfolding of events. In the Gospel of Luke, the angel Gabriel announces both the birth of John the Baptist to his father, Zechariah, and the miraculous birth of Jesus to his mother, Mary. It is angels who proclaim ‚Äúgood news of great joy‚Äù to the shepherds under the night sky. And, criti‚Ä¶

entry.title: The evolutionary case for a little roughhousing
entry.summary:
Wolf pups at play at Zoo Acad√©mie, a zoo and training facility in Nicolet, Quebec, in 2017. Scientists are finding that rough play is important for animals and humans alike. A variety of studies are showing that rough-and-tumble play is important for animals and kids alike.
Gordon Burghardt kept a lion cub named Meg in his home at the behest of the Knoxville Zoo. To help Meg get out some energy, Burghardt and his wife would often play with Meg in their wooded, unfenced backyard. One day, a neighbor‚Äôs dog appeared, tail wagging. As an ethologist‚Äîa scientist who studies animal behavior‚Äî Burghardt could see that the dog was giving clear signals that he wanted to play, not fight, but would the lion cub be able to read them? After all, these are two creatures separated by around 45 mill‚Ä¶

entry.title: Who was Pliny the Younger? How his words survived Pompeii
entry.summary:
Eyewitness to the tragic fate of Pompeii. Nephew of a great naturalist. Trusted public servant. Friend of emperors. Famed chronicler of the culture and politics of ancient Rome.¬†
Pliny the Younger was all of the above‚Äîand his accounts of what life was really like in his era have withstood the test of time. The statesman and keen witness of daily life wrote careful collections of letters that offer a rare, detailed, glimpse into a bygone world. Still relied on by modern readers, Pliny the Younger‚Äôs observations of historic events and daily life give a precious look into Roman life. Here‚Äôs what to know about the Roman administrator and letter-writer‚Äîand why his words are still studied today.¬†
Born around A.D. 61, Gaius Plinius Caecilius Secundus was the son of a wealthy famil‚Ä¶

entry.title: Democrats urge Trump to reverse mass ambassador recalls
entry.summary: Democratic senators urged President Donald Trump on Wednesday to reverse a recall of nearly 30 career ambassadors, warning the move leaves a dangerous leadership vacuum that allows adversaries like Russia and China to expand their influence.

entry.title: China's LandSpace hopes to complete rocket recovery in mid-2026
entry.summary: Chinese rocket developer LandSpace plans to successfully recover a reusable booster in mid-2026, a company executive said in an interview, underscoring the Beijing-based firm's ambition to become China's answer to SpaceX.

entry.title: Industrialisation without destruction: A UN blueprint for the future
entry.summary: Since the 19th century, industrialisation has had a transformative effect on the world, both positive and negative. It has created jobs and lifted millions out of poverty. But it has also had devastating consequences; destroying ecosystems, polluting the air, and driving the climate crisis that threatens to make large parts of the planet uninhabitable.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: Humanitarian response ongoing despite restrictions
entry.summary: Although ‚Äúsignificant restrictions and impediments‚Äù continue to hamper humanitarian operations in Gaza, teams are still responding to the population‚Äôs needs, the UN aid coordination office OCHA said on Wednesday.

entry.title: Paper and wood: Forest products show signs of recovery, UN agency says
entry.summary: From wood-based panels used in construction, to charcoal for cooking food, forest products are valued and traded all around the world.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Historic vote looms in Central African Republic as UN urges peaceful participation
entry.summary: With Central Africans set to vote in presidential, legislative, regional and long-delayed municipal elections this weekend, the United Nations has appealed for calm and restraint, warning that the credibility of the process will be critical to consolidating peace after years of conflict and instability.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN celebrates 10 years of progress in youth, peace and security agenda
entry.summary: The UN has long been at the forefront of efforts to involve young people in decision-making, and the last decade has seen significant progress, thanks to the adoption of a Security Council¬†Resolution on Youth, Peace and Security which led to widespread changes in the ways that the voices of young people are not just heard, but also incorporated in peace plans and policies.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: DOGE claims against reality
entry.summary: The farce that was DOGE made claims of heavy savings and government efficiency.‚Ä¶ Tags: DOGE, government, New York Times

entry.title: Thai and Cambodia militaries hold talks on resuming ceasefire
entry.summary: Sixteen days of border clashes have killed at least 86 people.

entry.title: Southeastern Taiwan shaken by 6.1 magnitude quake, no immediate reports of damage
entry.summary: An earthquake with a magnitude of 6.1 struck Taiwan's southeastern coastal county of Taitung on Wednesday, the island's weather administration said, although there were no immediate reports of damage.

entry.title: China's farmers are up to their ears in milk
entry.summary: Beijing's decision to apply tariffs on EU dairy imports may help.

entry.title: Tim Cook doubles his stake in Nike, shares rise
entry.summary: The Apple CEO, who has been on Nike's board since 2005, represents a vote of confidence in CEO Elliott Hill's efforts to revive demand.

entry.title: Russia plans a nuclear power plant on the moon within a decade
entry.summary: Russia plans to put a nuclear power plant on the moon in the next decade to supply its lunar space programme and a joint Russian-Chinese research station as major powers rush to explore the earth's only natural satellite.

entry.title: China says it opposes US tariffs on chips
entry.summary: China said on Wednesday that it opposed the United States' "indiscriminate use of tariffs" and "unreasonable suppression" of Chinese industries when asked about Washington's plan to impose tariffs on Chinese semiconductor imports.

entry.title: China probe finds Taiwanese smugglers controlled vessel that damaged subsea cables
entry.summary: Chinese authorities on Wednesday said two Taiwanese citizens led a smuggling operation involving a Chinese-crewed vessel that damaged subsea cables earlier this year.

entry.title: South Korean court rejects bid to block Korea Zinc share sale funding US smelter
entry.summary: A South Korean court on Wednesday rejected a request by two major shareholders of Korea Zinc - MBK Partners and YoungPoong - to block the zinc refiner's plan to issue new shares to help fund a $7.4 billion U.S. smelter.

author.name: Hyunjoo Jin, Heejin Kim, Heekyong Yang

entry.title: Stocks up as markets wind down to bumper year; gold and silver smash records
entry.summary: Asian shares advanced on Wednesday, capping a year of brisk artificial intelligence-driven gains, while commodities such as gold and silver extended their bullish run to new all-time highs as 2025 draws to a close.

entry.title: Venezuela resorts to floating storage as onshore storage tanks fill up
entry.summary: Venezuela's state-run oil company PDVSA has started filling tankers with crude and fuel oil and keeping them in Venezuelan waters, as inventories have mounted due to the U.S. seizing Venezuela-linked ships at sea, according to company documents and shipping data.

entry.title: US delays announcement of China chip tariffs until 2027
entry.summary: President Donald Trump's administration on Tuesday said it will slap tariffs on Chinese semiconductor imports over Beijing's "unreasonable" pursuit of chip industry dominance, but would delay the action until June 2027.

entry.title: China's commerce ministry urges US to drop drone supplier ban
entry.summary: China's commerce ministry urged the U.S. on Tuesday to stop the "wrong practice" of adding all foreign-made drone systems and key components to its new "Covered List", and it vowed measures to protect the rights and interests of Chinese firms.

entry.title: China's LandSpace completes 'tutoring' process ahead of Shanghai IPO
entry.summary: China's leading private rocket firm LandSpace has completed the so-called "tutoring" process for a potential initial public offering, a filing with the country's securities regulator showed on Tuesday, as Beijing looks to boost the domestic space industry by faciliating access to its capital markets.

entry.title: These 5 simple tests can reveal how well your body is aging
entry.summary:
Balancing on one leg may look simple, but it tests stability and neuromuscular control‚Äîkey abilities that tend to decline with age and influence fall risk. Experts say gait speed, grip strength, balance, and endurance are some of the strongest predictors of long-term independence. Here‚Äôs how to check them yourself‚Äîand what the results mean.
Aging doesn‚Äôt look the same for everyone. But research shows that independence and mobility are among the strongest indicators of how well someone is aging.
‚ÄúThe older we get, we experience changes in our joints and muscles and bodies that may lead us to slow down a little bit,‚Äù says Kaila Morin, a physical therapy supervisor at Gaylord Specialty Health. That slowing can lead to health issues or a rising risk of falls that result in broken ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Is this the ultimate alternative to hiking Peru's Inca Trail?
entry.summary:
Standing at 14,600ft, Kuychicassa Pass marks the summit of the three-day Quarry Trail. While the world-famous Inca Trail is undoutedly Peru‚Äôs headline hike, the Quarry Trail is a less-crowded alternative that‚Äôs just as rewarding.
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
‚ÄúWe‚Äôve reached the point of no return,‚Äù says my guide, Julio Llancay. It should sound ominous, but with that ever-present grin stretched across his face, it lands more like a punchline than a warning.
I‚Äôm standing at 11,411ft on a dusty track in the Sacred Valley, a few hours into the Quarry Trail. This 17-mile trek was created by Intrepid in collaboration with local Peruvians as a quieter, less-trodden alternative to the Inca Trail. Tomorrow, we‚Äôll climb even higher, peaking at 1‚Ä¶

entry.title: The radical wartime diet that saved Britain in World War II
entry.summary:
Eighty years since the end of World War II, the British are recalling many battles fought on the path to victory. Yet one seldom, if ever, gets mentioned, and it was one of the most consequential‚Äîthe battle to feed an island people under siege.
In the decade before the war, Britain imported around 22 million tons of food a year, almost two-thirds of its food supply. But early in 1940 Adolf Hitler set out to starve the British by sending swarms of submarines into the North Atlantic to sink the convoys of ships bringing essential foods from Canada and America. As a result, during the war, Britain‚Äôs food imports were halved to around 11.5 million tons.
Globally, more people died during the war of starvation than from military action, but the British never starved. In fact, they ate ‚Ä¶

entry.title: What scientists are still discovering about mistletoe
entry.summary:
Kissing under mistletoe is a practice that hearkens back to pagan fertility traditions‚Äîa joining together of random strangers, longtime lovers or the newly infatuated.
But most winter holiday revelers may not know that the biological reality of mistletoe plants is perhaps even more interesting and romantic than whatever goes on underneath them.¬†
For example, most mistletoe species would literally die without the host they are attached to. That‚Äôs because mistletoe is a widespread category of parasitic plants that grows on other plants, leeching water and other resources by tapping directly into the host‚Äôs root system. undefined undefined While this relationship can occasionally be deadly to the host plant, a growing body of research has revealed mistletoes are more of‚Ä¶

entry.title: How a climate scientist deals with ‚Äòtravel guilt‚Äô
entry.summary:
Among all the actions that can raise an individuals carbon footprint, flying is one of the biggest. But does that mean you should avoid vacation? Climate scientist Katharine Hayhoe reflects on flying, fossil fuels, and the tension between personal responsibility and systemic change in a warming world.
Katharine Hayhoe was raised to believe that science was ‚Äúthe coolest thing in the world.‚Äù
‚ÄúScience is a way of understanding how the universe and our planet works,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúAnd who wouldn‚Äôt want to understand that?‚Äù
Hayhoe is known not only for her research, but also for her ability to translate hard data into language people can easily understand. Chief Scientist for The Nature Conservancy and previously director of the Climate Center at Texas Tech University, she has sp‚Ä¶

entry.title: Watch the most thrilling‚Äîand the weirdest‚Äîwildlife videos of 2025
entry.summary:
An orca calf and adult swim in the Norwegian fjords. Orcas have been among the most popular subjects of social media videos. They have been filmed ramming into boats (possibly playing) and hunting with other species. From giant stick bugs to rarely seen sea creatures, these animal videos fascinated us‚Äîand led to new scientific discoveries. 
Spying on¬†animals is¬†getting easier¬†thanks to technology¬†like¬†drones,¬†remotely operated vehicles,¬†lightweight underwater cameras, and smart phones.¬†¬†
The animals we saw on video in 2025 fascinated and entertained us, like this colossal squid seen for the first time. Other videos documented the threats wildlife face, such as this unflinching look at a destructive fishing method. ¬†
And¬†of¬†course¬†it was no surprise to us¬†that many of‚Ä¶

entry.title: Take a road trip to the real home of St. Nicholas
entry.summary:
Before the iconic red suit and the sleigh, the real St. Nicholas lived and died in ancient Lycia, modern-day Antalya Province,¬†T√ºrkiye. St. Nick didn‚Äôt grow up with reindeer. He grew up walking among Roman marble, smelling salt in the air.¬†
‚ÄúBy all accounts, he was raised in a Christian family,‚Äù says Dr. Adam English,¬†Christian studies professor and author of¬†The Saint Who Would Be Santa Claus: The True Life and Trials of St. Nicholas of Myra. ‚ÄúAt that time, Christianity was still an illegal and minority faith, an occasionally persecuted faith. But by the time he dies, Christianity is now the accepted, approved, and endorsed religion of the empire. So, there‚Äôs a real sea change in the course of Nicholas‚Äô life.‚Äù
Travelers today can take a road trip through the Turkish Riviera ‚Ä¶

entry.title: UN Security Council hears warnings over escalating US-Venezuela standoff
entry.summary: Tensions between the United States and Venezuela have sharply escalated amid increased US military operations in the Southern Caribbean, prompting accusations of sovereignty violations, concerns over civilian harm and growing calls at the UN Security Council for restraint and de-escalation.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Overnight strikes leave death, destruction and power outages in Ukraine
entry.summary: A new wave of overnight strikes and front-line hostilities in Ukraine have caused further civilian casualties and damage to critical energy infrastructure, the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) said on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Gaza aid restrictions, Syria humanitarian needs, lawyer reprisals in Burundi
entry.summary: The UN and partners continue to provide assistance to people in Gaza, where recent winter storms have worsened conditions for thousands across the enclave.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Myanmar elections marked by fear as UN warns civilians are coerced from all sides
entry.summary: As Myanmar approaches elections scheduled for 28 December, the UN‚Äôs top human rights official has said that civilians are being coerced from all sides ‚Äì forced by the military to vote and threatened by armed opposition groups to boycott ‚Äì in a climate of fear, violence and mass repression.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Security Council remains divided over Iran nuclear programme, sanctions stay in place
entry.summary: At a meeting to discuss nuclear non-proliferation on Tuesday, the Security Council‚Äôs stance on Iran‚Äôs nuclear activities remained divided on the issue, split between those who support the reinstatement of sanctions, and the members who believe the sanctions should be permanently lifted, whilst questioning the legality of the meeting itself.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: DR Congo: Displaced people in South Kivu close to ‚Äòutter desperation‚Äô, WFP says
entry.summary: An estimated 500,000 people have been forced from their homes since fighting erupted in South Kivu province, Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), at the beginning of December.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: LIVE: Security Council meets on Somalia, Iran
entry.summary: The Security Council convenes today for a packed agenda. At 10 am, members are set to vote on a draft resolution extending the mandate of the African Union support mission in Somalia (AUSSOM), which supports Somali authorities in stabilisation efforts and the fight against armed groups. The Council will then hear a briefing on Iran and the implementation of resolution 2231, which endorsed the 2015 nuclear deal, known as the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA). Members are also scheduled to convene for a meeting in the afternoon on threats to international peace and security. Follow live below and UN News app users can click here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: China launches trade dispute against India over solar cells and IT goods
entry.summary: China has launched a trade dispute with India over solar cells, solar modules and IT goods, requesting dispute consultations on the matter, the World Trade Organization said on Tuesday.

entry.title: K-Pop concert to be held in Hong Kong and aired in mainland China, organisers say
entry.summary: A K-Pop concert will be held in Hong Kong in February and aired across mainland China by a state-run broadcaster, the organiser said, amid growing hopes of cultural exchanges between China and South Korea after nearly a decade of an unofficial ban.

entry.title: Spain set to re-enter Germany's top 10 export markets as shipments jump
entry.summary: Spain is set to become the fastest-growing destination among Germany's 10 biggest export markets in 2025, with shipments forecast to rise 8.5% to 58.8 billion euros ($69.31 billion), a Germany Trade & Invest (GTAI) projection showed.

entry.title: Vanke may adopt a familiar playbook in China to tackle debt crisis, say analysts
entry.summary: State-backed China Vanke will likely mirror the strategies of some other cash-strapped Chinese developers and seek multiple short-term extensions for its bond repayments before ultimately proposing a debt restructuring, credit analysts said.

entry.title: Invisible infrared surveillance technology and those caught in its digital cage
entry.summary: When you unlock a phone, step into view of a security camera or drive past a license plate reader at night, beams of infrared light - invisible to the naked eye ‚Äî shine onto the unique contours of your face, your body, your license plate lettering.

entry.title: From the Pitch Stage to the Write Up, the Line Edit to Publication: How Editors Can Help Investigative Stories
entry.summary: An editor can play a pivotal role in making or breaking a story‚Äôs impact. From narrowing complex stories to ensuring accuracy, great editing turns strong reporting into powerful journalism.

entry.title: HSBC's Ann Godbehere to retire as chair search ends with Nelson's appointment
entry.summary: HSBC Holdings said on Tuesday that Ann Godbehere, its senior independent director and board member who led the search for a new chair, would step down and retire at the bank's 2026 annual general meeting due to "personal and lifestyle reasons".

entry.title: Global investors turn to Chinese AI as Wall Street fears bubble
entry.summary: Global investors are increasing their wagers on Chinese artificial intelligence companies, betting on the next DeepSeek and seeking to diversify, with concerns growing about a speculative bubble in the sector on Wall Street.

entry.title: China urges US to fulfill nuclear disarmament responsibility after Pentagon report
entry.summary: China on Tuesday urged the United States to fulfill its nuclear disarmament responsibilities after a draft Pentagon report said China is likely to have loaded more than 100 intercontinental ballistic missiles and has no desire for arms control talks.

entry.title: Chinese envoy urges Thailand-Cambodia to resume ceasefire as soon as possible
entry.summary: The top priority for Thailand and Cambodia is to agree to a ceasefire and stop fighting as soon as possible resume dialogue, and resolve their border disputes peacefully, a special Chinese envoy to the region said.

entry.title: EU plans checks against cheap plastic imports, FT says
entry.summary: The European Union is planning checks on imported plastics and other steps to support its recycling industry, the Financial Times reported on Tuesday.

entry.title: Trump announces plans for new Navy ‚Äòbattleship‚Äô as part of a ‚ÄòGolden Fleet‚Äô
entry.summary: U.S. President Donald Trump announced a bold plan on Monday for the Navy to build a new, large warship that he called a ‚Äúbattleship‚Äù as part of a larger vision to create a "Golden Fleet."

entry.title: Stocks, precious metals rise; yen on intervention watch
entry.summary: Asia shares rose alongside precious metals on Tuesday as momentum buying from investors extended ahead of the festive holidays, with an advanced reading on U.S. GDP expected later in the day.

entry.title: US drops plan to deport Chinese national who exposed Xinjiang abuses, rights activists say
entry.summary: The Department of Homeland Security has dropped its plan to deport a Chinese national who entered the country illegally after his plight raised public concerns that the man, if deported, would be punished by Beijing for helping expose human rights abuses in China‚Äôs Xinjiang region.

entry.title: FCC bans new Chinese-made drones, citing security risks
entry.summary: The Federal Communications Commission says it will ban new foreign-made drones, a move that will keep new Chinese-made drones out of the U.S. market.

entry.title: Report says Amtrak's new higher-speed trains delayed by planning, track issues
entry.summary: U.S. passenger railroad Amtrak's next-generation high-speed Acela train cars were delayed by more than four years due to planning, design and track issues, and a desire for higher speeds that have not materialized, a Senate report issued late on Monday said.

entry.title: US lawmakers want disclosure of license reviews for Nvidia H200 chip sales to China
entry.summary: Two senior Democratic lawmakers on Monday asked the U.S. Commerce Department to disclose details and any approvals of ongoing license reviews for potential sales to Chinese firms of Nvidia's second-most powerful AI chips.

entry.title: FACTBOX Driverless future gains momentum with global robotaxi deployments
entry.summary: Ride-hailing firms and technology companies around the world are racing to deploy driverless taxis, betting that robotaxis will reshape urban transport and unlock new growth as regulation gradually opens up.

entry.title: 7 ways to hike across South Korea
entry.summary:
South Korea's Jeju Island is aptly nicknamed the "Hawaii of Korea." Nearly three-fourths of the country is mountainous, with myriad hiking opportunities for beginners and experts alike.
Walking and hiking have been part of Korean life for generations, and it's easy to understand why, as 70 percent of the country is mountainous and a number of ancient temples are placed along the slopes.
‚ÄúThe peaks in Korea are all steep and sharp, hence very physical,‚Äù says Roger Shepherd, who runs Hike Korea and has written a guidebook about hiking the Baekdudaegan mountain range. ‚ÄúThey are covered in old foot trails (yet-gil) and temples from before industrialization, with layers of recreational trails added over the decades.‚Äù
Korea‚Äôs hiking trails are accommodating to beginners and e‚Ä¶

entry.title: Was Christmas moved to eclipse Rome's Saturnalia festival?
entry.summary:
Every December, billions celebrate the birth of Jesus Christ with rituals that feel timeless: candlelight, evergreen branches, and winter hymns. None of these seasonal details, however, come from the Bible‚Äînor does the New Testament identify the date or time of year when Jesus was born. Luke‚Äôs Gospel does mention shepherds watching their flocks by night, a detail some have taken to imply a warmer season. Beyond this, the biblical writers provide no clues for the placement of Christmas.
This gap in the scriptural record left later generations of Christians with considerable interpretive freedom. As Christianity expanded across the Roman Empire and developed liturgical holidays to commemorate key events in Jesus‚Äô life, the question of when to celebrate his birth became increasingly impo‚Ä¶

entry.title: The winter drink you need to know about‚ÄîTurin‚Äôs bicerin
entry.summary:
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
The Italian city of Turin is renowned for its centuries-old cafe culture and rich chocolate confectionary, so it stands to reason that it‚Äôs also the birthplace of bicerin. Meaning ‚Äòlittle glass‚Äô in the local Piedmontese dialect (‚Äòbiccherino‚Äô in Italian), this warming, decadent drink comprising layers of thick, melted chocolate and espresso with barely whipped cream has been served at Turin‚Äôs Caffe il Bicerin since the 18th century. The drink quickly became a feature in cafes across the city, to the point where today it‚Äôs considered a symbol of not just Turin, but of the surrounding Alp-studded region, too. Its fans are legion; Ernest Hemingway, who stopped in Turin after the First World War, wrote that bicerin was one o‚Ä¶

entry.title: These are New England‚Äôs most beautiful garden cemeteries
entry.summary:
Cemeteries like Concord, Massachusetts‚Äô Sleepy Hollow, pictured here, reveal New England‚Äôs unique history and culture. Borne from a Victorian-era landscape movement, these sites tell the tales of the Salem witch trials, the Revolutionary War, and the movement that fostered literary legends.
Historic cemeteries are among New England‚Äôs most surprising cultural landscapes. Far from the macabre, these sites were ‚Äúdesigned as a tranquil, natural setting ‚Ä¶ to inspire and comfort the living,‚Äù wrote Blanche Linden-Ward in her seminal work Silent City on a Hill about the 19th-century landscape movement that sought to reimagine graveyards as rural gardens.
Today, that original vision is evident across the region in burial grounds that feel like arboretums, wildlife refuges, and outdoor ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Is melatonin good for heart health? Depends who you are.
entry.summary:
Melatonin may be one of America‚Äôs most trusted sleep aids, but scientists are still untangling what it actually does to the heart‚Äîand the story is more complicated than most consumers realize. Some studies point to melatonin use as beneficial to heart health, while others say the opposite. Here‚Äôs how to make sense of the complex research.
Along with being a hormone naturally produced in the brain, melatonin is one of the most widely used sleep supplements in the United States,¬†with¬†millions of people taking it¬†in hopes of a¬†better night's rest.¬†
The supplement is often marketed to consumers as a gentle, ‚Äúnatural‚Äù remedy that is widely perceived as benign. Yet the science surrounding its effects beyond sleep‚Äîparticularly on the heart‚Äîis far more complex and unsettled than many ‚Ä¶

entry.title: 5 of the most beautiful monasteries in Armenia
entry.summary:
The Tatev Monastery is just one of five UNESCO-listed religious sites worth visiting in Armenia, the world‚Äôs first Christian nation. From cliff-carved chapels to highland fortresses, these UNESCO-recognized sites bring travelers face to face with 17 centuries of ritual and craftsmanship. 
Since Armenia‚Äôs adoption of Christianity in 301 C.E., the nation‚Äôs monasteries have been central to its worship traditions. After 17 centuries, these UNESCO-recognized sites became deep community anchors, both reflecting and carving the culture of the world‚Äôs first Christian nation. Today, Armenia still enjoys ‚Äòunder-tourism‚Äô, and these religious sites are well worth exploring.¬†
(This trail reveals the wonders of Armenia‚Äîa country at the crossroads of the world.)
While the origina‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why most health resolutions fail
entry.summary:
Every January, millions of people set ambitious health goals. Research suggests that the habits most likely to improve long-term health‚Äîand actually stick‚Äîare often simpler and more sustainable than popular wellness trends. As wellness advice floods social media, experts point to a short list of science-backed habits that improve health‚Äîand a few popular resolutions you‚Äôre better off skipping.
Every January, millions of people resolve to improve their health. Many start with dramatic overhauls‚Äîcutting out entire food groups, committing to daily workouts, or vowing to reinvent their routines overnight. By February, those overly optimistic resolutions unravel, not for lack of motivation, but because they were unsustainable.
That doesn‚Äôt mean accomplishing your goals is a lost ca‚Ä¶

entry.title: Visiting St Lucia with teens? Here's what to do
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
St Lucia offers an ideal mix of comfortable hotels, dreamy Caribbean beaches and active adventures for families ‚Äî and it‚Äôs a combination that works particularly well for those with teens, who can be harder to please and entertain. Your family could be snorkelling with squid and turtles one day, then scrambling up the island‚Äôs majestic Gros Piton mountain the next, before feasting on chocolate that kids can even try making themselves with pods plucked from accessible jungle trails. ¬†
Pristine volcanic black and golden sand beaches are the star attraction in St Lucia. Anse Chastanet ‚Äî and sister Anse Mamin beach, connected by a short coastal walkway ‚Äî are two particularly renowned for their striking sand. Both offe‚Ä¶

entry.title: Is the grumpy-faced Texas horned lizard cute enough to survive?
entry.summary:
Out-of-state visitors may not know what they‚Äôre looking at, but fans of Texas Christian University (TCU) get fired up when SuperFrog runs onto the football field. Human-size and gray, with pointy protrusions on its head and spiky, Popeye-like forearms, SuperFrog is the school‚Äôs mascot, meant to induce fear in the hearts of opposing teams. SuperFrog‚Äôs real-life inspiration, though, isn‚Äôt quite as intimidating.
TCU‚Äôs mascot is based on a creature that‚Äôs at most four inches long and almost comically sedate, with a pancake-shaped body and grumpy face under thorny crowns. It‚Äôs not even technically a frog‚Äîor, as many Texans refer to it, a horned toad. It‚Äôs a Texas horned lizard, and the rest of the state loves the real thing just as much as TCU loves SuperFrog.
While not a keystone spe‚Ä¶

entry.title: What should I do with this ancient Maya pot?
entry.summary: As a kid, I loved rummaging around my uncle‚Äôs makeshift museum. Wilfred Sylvester was an enthusiastic amateur historian and collector of remarkable artifacts, and he had transformed two rooms of my grandmother‚Äôs house in Louisiana into an extensive gallery. Revolutionary War flintlocks and Civil War muskets lined the walls. Glass display cases held 400-year-old French Bibles and Confederate dollar bills. There was a miniature replica of a Roman catapult next to a German World War I helmet with the spike on top. But the item that captured my imagination most was a small pot no bigger than an orange. It had a human face molded into the terra-cotta and a hole bored through the rim, suggesting someone had once worn it around the neck. The pot was Maya, and I imagined an artist using it to hold‚Ä¶

entry.title: See the next solar eclipse from a true dark sky zone
entry.summary:
Witness the next solar eclipse from the middle of the ocean. In August 2026, a total solar eclipse will be visible over parts of Spain, Portugal, and a large chunk of the Atlantic and Arctic Oceans. These cruises will take you into the path of totality.
When the sun, Earth, and new moon perfectly align, we get the chance to see a solar eclipse. This celestial phenomenon is one of the most unique experiences you can witness. In fact, the most recent total solar eclipse across the United States drew millions of people outside to see nightfall in the middle of the day. On August 12, 2026, the next solar eclipse's path of totality is going over a large chunk of the Atlantic and Arctic Oceans, which means that a cruise may be the best way to see it.
Many of the best family-friendly‚Ä¶

entry.title: China confirms talks between Wingtech, Nexperia BV, urges further negotiations
entry.summary: China on Monday confirmed that Wingtech and Nexperia B.V. had held the first round of talks last week, with both sides agreeing to maintain communications, according to a statement released by China's commerce ministry.

entry.title: Exclusive: China likely loaded more than 100 ICBMs in silo fields, Pentagon report says
entry.summary: China is likely to have loaded more than 100 intercontinental ballistic missiles across three silo fields and has no desire for arms control talks, according to a draft Pentagon report which highlighted Beijing's growing military ambitions.

author.name: Gregor Martynus, Lars Grammel, Aayush Kapoor, Josh Singh, Nico Albanese

entry.title: Russia is ready to legally confirm that it has no intention of attacking NATO, deputy minister says
entry.summary: Russia is ready to confirm in a legal agreement that it has no intention of attacking either the European Union or the U.S.-led NATO military alliance, Russian Deputy Foreign Minister Sergei Ryabkov said on Monday, the state RIA news agency reported.

entry.title: Exclusive: Nvidia aims to begin H200 chip shipments to China by mid-February
entry.summary: Nvidia has told Chinese clients it aims to start shipping its second-most powerful AI chips to China before the Lunar New Year holiday in mid-February, three people familiar with the matter told Reuters.

entry.title: Porsche to wind down charging network in tough China market, agency reports
entry.summary: Porsche plans to shut down its charging infrastructure in China next year, a Chinese news agency reported on Monday, in another sign of struggle for Volkswagen's luxury subsidiary in the tough Chinese market.

entry.title: UN warns Sudan war entering deadlier phase as fighting spreads in Kordofan
entry.summary: The war in Sudan is entering a deadlier phase, the United Nations has warned, as intensified fighting in the Kordofan region, mounting civilian casualties from drone strikes and growing risks of regional spillover push the conflict toward the 1,000-day mark.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Somalia: Funding cuts impact assistance to millions affected by drought
entry.summary: Brutal slashes to aid budgets are hampering efforts to assist millions of people in Somalia affected by drought, the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) said on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Winter aid delivery continues in Gaza
entry.summary: Despite the ceasefire in the Gaza Strip, humanitarians continue to receive reports of airstrikes, shelling and gunfire in all five governorates, the United Nations said on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Weekend attacks in Ukraine bring more casualties, damage infrastructure
entry.summary: Hostilities in Ukraine this weekend resulted in more civilian casualties and widespread damage to critical infrastructure, the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) reported on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: LIVE: Security Council meets on escalating violence in Sudan
entry.summary: Senior UN political and humanitarian officials are set brief the Security Council this afternoon as members meet to discuss the rapidly deteriorating situation in Sudan, where intensified fighting ‚Äì including in the Kordofan region ‚Äì has driven widespread civilian harm and displacement. The region has seen a sharp escalation, including a deadly drone attack on a UN peacekeeping base that killed six Bangladeshi peacekeepers. The meeting was requested by Sudan and Transitional Prime Minister, Kamil Eltayeb Idris, is expected to attend. Follow live below and UN News app users can click here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Synthetic drug market disrupted in Syria after regime change
entry.summary: Past geopolitical tensions related to the synthetic drug ‚Äúcaptagon‚Äù are now being mitigated with the Syrian authorities‚Äô commitment to dismantle illicit manufacturing, says the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Marrying a ChatGPT-driven virtual partner
entry.summary: A woman in Japan ‚Äúmarried‚Äù her virtual partner in a real-world ceremony. Such‚Ä¶ Tags: ChatGPT, relationships, Reuters

entry.title: Voices of Russia
entry.summary: In rare interviews, Russians speak candidly about their lives in the presence of war ‚Äì animated to protect their identities - by Aeon Video Watch on Aeon

entry.title: Are doctors replaceable?
entry.summary: Medical error kills hundreds of thousands yearly. If AI is sophisticated enough to help, doctors must not stand in the way - by Charlotte Blease Read on Aeon

entry.title: Russia's pipeline gas exports to China seen up 25% this year, source says
entry.summary: Russia's pipeline exports of natural gas to China are expected to have risen by a quarter this year, a source familiar with the data told Reuters on Monday, as Moscow ramps up sales to Asia and cements ties with the world's largest energy consumer.

entry.title: Uber, Lyft partner with Baidu for UK robotaxi trials next year
entry.summary: Uber and Lyft said on Monday they were teaming up with Chinese tech giant Baidu to launch driverless taxi trials in the UK next year, reinforcing the country's role as Europe's leading testbed for commercializing robotaxis.

entry.title: GIJN‚Äôs 10 Must-Read Stories of 2025
entry.summary: GIJN's top stories from the past year, including cutting-edge reporting tools and techniques, in-person conference presentations, and analysis of the state of the IJ community.

entry.title: China hits EU dairy products with provisional duties
entry.summary: China will impose provisional duties of 21.9% to 42.7% on certain dairy products imported from the European Union starting on December 23, following an anti-subsidy probe that began more than a year ago.

entry.title: Trump shook up global trade this year; some uncertainty may persist in 2026
entry.summary: President Donald Trump's return to the White House in 2025 kicked off a frenetic year for global trade, with waves of tariffs on U.S. trading partners that lifted import taxes to their highest since the Great Depression, roiled financial markets and sparked rounds of negotiations over trade and investment deals.

entry.title: China leaves benchmark lending rates unchanged for seventh straight month
entry.summary: China left benchmark loan prime rates (LPRs) unchanged for the seventh consecutive month in December on Monday, matching market expectations.

entry.title: Asia shares extend tech rally, yen under pressure
entry.summary: Asian share markets rose on Monday tracking tech-driven gains on Wall Street, while the yen wallowed at all-time lows against the euro and Swiss franc as higher interest rates at home did nothing to deter speculative sellers.

entry.title: China's power reforms, global data centre buildout usher in battery boom
entry.summary: A revamp of China's electricity market is boosting the economics of storing power just as international demand surges, sparking a boom for the Chinese energy storage manufacturers that already dominate globally.

entry.title: Cambodia, Thailand to hold talks on resuming Trump's truce as fighting enters third week
entry.summary: Thailand and Cambodia agreed on Monday to hold a December 24 meeting of defence officials towards resuming a months-old ceasefire, as fierce border fighting between them entered a third week with at least 80 people killed so far.

entry.title: How to plan a family ski trip, according to an expert
entry.summary:
Families can take to the snowy slopes in Serre Chevalier on skis, sleds or snowboards. From bagging one of Europe‚Äôs few bargains to what not to pack, get your first family skiing trip off to a flying start with our expert guide.
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
For many parents the idea of whisking your family off to the mountains one winter and learning to ski is a potent daydream. But it‚Äôs also strewn with both potential pitfalls and actual physical falls ‚Äî and eye-watering costs. But there‚Äôs a good reason why millions love it and return to the slopes year after year. One good day, skiing together in the sunshine, can light up a whole winter. Here‚Äôs how to improve your chances of a successful first trip.
Don‚Äôt rush into it. The m‚Ä¶

entry.title: Italy's Saipem wins offshore contract in Qatar for about $4 billion
entry.summary: Italy's Saipem said on Sunday it had been awarded an offshore engineering, procurement, construction and installation (EPCI) contract by QatarEnergy LNG in partnership with China's Offshore Oil Engineering Co (COOEC) .

entry.title: South Korea's An, Frenchman Popov win World Tour Finals
entry.summary: South Korea's An Se-young won the women's World Tour Finals with a 21-13 18-21 21-10 win over defending champion Wang Zhiyi, while France's Christo Popov beat world champion Shi Yuqi 21-19 21-9 to win the men's title on Sunday.
